video.title: Self-Driving Car with JavaScript Course – Neural Networks and Machine Learning
video.description:
Learn how to create a neural network using JavaScript with no libraries. In this course you will learn to make a self-driving car simulation by implementing every component step-by-step. You will learn how to implement the car driving mechanics, how to define the environment, how to simulate some sensors, how to detect collisions, and how to make the car control itself using a neural network.

The course covers how artificial neural networks work, by comparing them with the real neural networks in our brain. You will learn how to implement a neural network and how to visualize it so we can see it in action.

✏️ Dr. Radu Mariescu-Istodor created this course. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC3XGlNq8O5hZlZBJlSFB4jg

💻 Code: https://github.com/gniziemazity/Self-driving-car

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:03:44) Car driving mechanics
⌨️ (0:32:26) Defining the road
⌨️ (0:50:50) Artificial sensors
⌨️ (1:10:07) Collision detection
⌨️ (1:23:20) Simulating traffic
⌨️ (1:34:57) Neural network
⌨️ (2:03:10) Parallelization
⌨️ (2:18:31) Genetic algorithm
⌨️ (2:29:40) Ending

⭐️ Links ⭐️
🔗 Radu's website (with enhanced version of code): https://radufromfinland.com
🔗 Radu's workplace (consider applying): https://karelia.fi/en/front-page
🔗 Segment intersection (Math and JavaScript code): https://youtu.be/fHOLQJo0FjQ
🔗 Visualizing a neural network in JavaScript: https://youtu.be/lok3RVBwSqE
🔗 Visualizer code: https://radufromfinland.com/projects/selfdrivingcar/visualizer.js
🔗 Drawing random color cars in JavaScript: https://youtu.be/SL6PfDpSjao

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: blasttrash
topLevelComment.text: just curious, this is working without backpropagation? the network only has feedforward right? no minimization of cost whatsoever?

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: No backpropagation. Optimization is done using some genetic algorithm, but because the scenario is relatively simple, small networks work as well and optimizing those is relatively easy. I will make a part 2 to this course sometime in spring / summer where I will complicate the scenario. Might use backpropagation there if needed.

replies.author: Alex Peirson
replies.text: In case you've not fixed it, for me the issue was the fact that car.draw(ctx) on line 7 in main.js was being called before animate(). Removing car.draw(ctx) from line 7 in main.js and placing it in to animate() (before ctx.restore()) fixed this.. Thanks to Zoheb Ahmad (and any others) in the comments below for pointing this out!

replies.author: John Busciglio
replies.text: this one caught me too.  I might have figured it out, but I got distracted by the the sensor draw method starting out inside the update method.  i should take a break it's been an hour!  Thanks for asking this question tho, saved me some cycles

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @Zoheb Ahmad Ah, yes, that one. Few others also didn't notice I moved it inside animate (not copied). If you call it before car.update, it will try to draw the sensor before it has information about the rays.

replies.author: Zoheb Ahmad
replies.text: OMG IT'S THE "car.draw(ctx)" BEFORE THE animate() IN main.js THAT WAS CAUSING ALL THIS TROUBLE!!! DON'T KNOW HOW ANY OF THIS WORKS BUT THAT WAS THE PROBLEM!!!

replies.author: Zoheb Ahmad
replies.text:
@Radu Mariescu-Istodor Somehow changing the this.rayCount in the for loop in the draw method to this.rays.length fixes the error...
Now my sensors work perfectly! However, only inside the for loop (ensuring the for loop uses this.rays.length and nothing else... not even a constant integer)

topLevelComment.author: David P
topLevelComment.text: 50:10 - Could someone please explain why exactly this works? I get it’s shifting the canvas center, but why does it have this effect? And why is car.y negative? Awesome course so far by the way!

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @David P I think your explanation is very good. Thanks :-) Hope people stumble upon it!

replies.author: David P
replies.text: @Radu Mariescu-Istodor After I wrote this comment I thought about it a bit more so I’ll try to explain how I understand it to the best of my ability for anyone else wondering how it works: Due to the canvas center being moved down by car.y pixels and the car then being drawn car.y pixels above the center the car is always drawn at the same point, while the road is always drawn from the canvas center - infinity to the canvas center + infinity, so as the canvas center is moving down with the car moving up, the road is getting “dragged” down and it looks like the car is riding on the road.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: Hmmm, I tried writing a comment explaining it, but I'm not happy with it :-( I'll probably make a video on these canvas transformation courses at some point after the beginner course on canvas I'm currently creating. Maybe stay tuned for that :-)

topLevelComment.author: Tammo Dirksen
topLevelComment.text: I haven’t watched this yet but it looks super interesting. Before I dive into it can someone answer me why JavaScript and not Python or is Python involved as well? I am just asking because I have seen a lot of Python Deep Learning stuff with libraries like PyTorch and so on.

replies.author: Tammo Dirksen
replies.text: @Radu Mariescu-Istodor That makes sense to me. And what you said about using a ton of libraries is true. As a beginner you should learn the fundamentals first. So I appreciate it a lot that this course does that. And thanks for the quick response. :)

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: I chose JavaScript because machine learning is not very common in JS. Meaning, that those who know JavaScript probably don't know much machine learning (so, I get a wider audience in this way). I don't use libraries, so, you can likely follow along in other languages as well, if you feel confident. At work I teach this in Python as well with and without libraries. Problem with libraries is that many people jump in and think they know what they're doing without understanding the basics :-)

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Ferrin
topLevelComment.text:
third attempt is a charm?? maybe you do not like the link......

Why not just make a self learning AI, that you can ask to create a self driving car? Relax.. I am just joking.. or am I? For those that dabble, openai among a myriad of other of uses has a neatly contained JS sandbox, which you can task with whatever and it will try to create/draw it for you.  beta DOT openai DOT com SLASH codex-javascript-sandbox . Its actually pretty smart but needed some help understanding user input and basic car mechanics. Here is my dabbling that will get you a little red car that drives similar to a real car and wraps the canvas. parallax scrolling is very simple to switch over to upon reaching that point in creation. here are the three prompts(preceded with p:) and comments(preceded with #'s): 
## initial prompt sent processing, there are 2 addition prompts (with respective comment)
p: Create a red car on a light grey background that the user may drive with keyboard controls. The dimensions of the car are 20 units wide by 35 units long. The car has properties for x position, y position, current velocity, max velocity, direction angle, acceleration rate and steering rate. The cars current velocity is 0. The cars direction angle is 0. The cars max velocity is 10 units per second. The car acceleration rate is 1 unit per second squared. The car steering rate is 10 degrees per second squared. Create a function to recieve input from the user. The up keyboard key increases the cars current velocity by the cars acceleration rate. The cars current velocity can not be greater than the cars max velocity. The down keyboard key decreases the cars current velocity by the inverse of the cars acceleration rate. The cars current velocity can not be lesser than the inverse of the cars max velocity. The left arrow key decreases the cars direction angle by the cars steering rate. When the cars direction angle is less than 0 degrees the cars direction angle is set to 360 degrees. The right arrow key increases the cars direction angle by the cars steering rate. When the cars direction angle is greater than 360 degrees the cars direction angle is set to 0 degrees. Create an update function that calculates the cars x and y position using the cars velocitiy, acceleration and direction. If the cars x position is greater than 600 units it is set to 0. If the cars x position is less than 0 it is set to 600. If the cars y position is greater than 400 units it is set to 0. If the cars y position is less than 0 it is set to 400. Create an animate function that displays the car on the screen. The function uses requestAnimationFrame to simulate smooth animation to the user. The function redraws the screen only if the cars x or y position have changed since last function call. 

## needed to reset =)
p: create function to reset car. this function will set cars x to 50, y to 50, current velocity to 0 and direction angle to 0.

## needed some reality =D
p: add a decelerate function to the car. this function will apply a deceleration factor of 0.05 per second squared to cars current velocity until the cars velocity has reached 0. add a keyIsDown property to the car. update the input function to set the keyIsDown to true if a keyboard key up or keyboard key down is currently being pressed and false otherwise. update the cars update function to call the cars deceleration function if keyIsDown is not true.

## LOL I sure did oof that if you are following along. the fix which should have been original implimentation(you can easily modify it if you want!). I personally like throwing these live edits at the ai because its fun to think about if it's "smart" enough to figure it out and then watching it actually solve the issue so elegantly, and I also threw in a more abstract concept of 'truth table' =D
p: create a function to detect input function from user and set a truth table of key up and key down for the keyboard up, down, left and right arrow keys. update the cars input function use the values from truth table instead of directly detecting key press.

topLevelComment.author: Navya Vedachala
topLevelComment.text: 16:50 important tip about using arrow functions instead of function declaration within classes. Arrow functions mean that this.left refer to controls as the context. If we did function declaration, this would refer to the function as the context and as there is no this.left within functions, it would lead to errors.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: Glad to hear you like it :-) gradient descent is something similar in nature to what we do in the mutation step. Small changes in the settings which result in an improvement mean our error is going down. But true gradient descent doesn't rely on randomness here, and is a bit smarter and more complicated, but if you understand this basic logic you may find gradient descent easier next time you look. I might make some regression-related videos in the future, let's see :-)

topLevelComment.author: Alexander Zelenkov
topLevelComment.text:
I followed just a first part of this great video and I have a question.
I am from airspace background and for me rotation of car and moving along X axis is a bit complicated (flip, angle could reach huge value). In airspace usually just add another system of coordinate (x',y',z') and just rotate one relatively another. 
Is it possible in JS or this would be over-complicated solution not suitable for self drive mode?

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @Alexander Zelenkov Ok. Thanks. I know the concepts, just haven't really thought of applying it for a game like this. I'll consider it :-)

replies.author: Alexander Zelenkov
replies.text: @Radu Mariescu-Istodor Oh, yes 2D sorry. Than we can have two system XY and X’Y’. XY is coordinate on our canvas and X’Y’ is coordinate of car (relatively of car, i.e. inside a car). Car on canvas moving in X and Y direction, but in X’Y’ system car movies only along X’ axis and the whole X’Y’ system rotate. I am not sure about links attached to comments but you can check idea with googling “global and local coordinate system” It is common topic in airspace design.

topLevelComment.author: Tiziano Lena
topLevelComment.text:
Extremely cool project! I have a few questions about this kind of 'learning' (I jumped a bit random in video so please sorry if all got answered)
1. is really this kind of neural network a black box? I mean after training you have no clue of WHY the AI chooses to move in a way, right?
2. when you train the AI, I'm worried that you developer are training to beat a specific combination of cars or a track. How can you be sure that the training on a kind of situation 'A' is really good also for every other? If there is a problem in simulation A and I genetically modify with randomness and 'fix' A, how can I be sure that the AI then loses the capability to successfully beat the simulation B (a little or much different)?

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @Tiziano Lena Haha Ok :-) hope you'll like the course!

replies.author: Tiziano Lena
replies.text: @Radu Mariescu-Istodor thank you! I did a test to learn myself a little of NN with a Unity C# small app that tries to solve the good old 'Frogger' game. I found your video interesting and hope to see more of your course. Count me as a subscriber as my little NN frog is getting squashed a lot! ;-)

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text:
Good questions :-)
1. Well, the small networks we generate here are still possible to understand to some degree. It's possible to visualize few more things that makes it even easier, but I didn't add those to this course (planning a future one). But this network is not very useful for real self-driving where you have to detect pedestrians and other obstacles, read traffic signs, cope in varying weather conditions, etc. There the network is huge in comparison and if it does something bad... it's hard to say why.
2. You test... A test setup should contain thousands of simulations. If fixing something in A, breaks the others in a significant way, it will show in the average result.

topLevelComment.author: David Murphy
topLevelComment.text: Hmm. Why did they go with JavaScript... I know js - everyone does - but Python is so much nicer to code. I follow the "avoid js if at all possible" route. It's slow though, I'll grant. I suppose it would be easy enough to watch and do it in Python.

replies.author: David Murphy
replies.text:
@Radu Mariescu-Istodor Right, uploaded a second video during lunch. It wasn't the best run actually, sometimes you hit a local minimum which the net isn't well configured to deal with. It's only the baseline NN you suggested, nothing clever happening. I gave cars with numbers <5 low variation and cars >15 high variation in an effort to prevent regression. 

The best case is first corner in five gens and a full lap in 12 with 20 instances. I then increase the velocity with each completed lap. Anyway, I added a minimap and tracked the success of each gen.

replies.author: Radu Mariescu-Istodor
replies.text: @David Murphy Yes, sure, I'd like to see! I also tried htan, sigmoid and relu and remember relu being the best in my case too.

replies.author: David Murphy
replies.text:
@Radu Mariescu-Istodor Ok, just had another crack at it. Gave up on respawning a single vehicle (too slow), added multi-threading spawned 20. Wasn't going very well, the variation in the output was very low. Then I switched from sigmoid to ReLU (min/max clamp) and it was night and day, within a few generations it was driving round the track.

I'm off to the gym now but I'll post a vid at some point if you're interested.
